channel.title: NYT > Science
channel.copyright: Copyright 2026 The New York Times Company

item.title: Filoplumes Are Nature’s Super Feather
item.description: Filoplumes may be tiny, but these hairlike feathers enable nonstop flights that span thousands of miles.
item.dc:creator: Jim Robbins and Bryan Anselm
item.media:credit: Bryan Anselm for The New York Times

item.title: Thing-Like Robotic Hand Makes Life Resemble ‘The Addams Family’
item.description: The very capable robotic picker-upper can grasp things on both sides and roam around freely.
item.dc:creator: Ari Daniel

item.title: How to Cut an Infinitely Large Pancake into as Many Pieces as Possible
item.description: A team of mathematicians seeks to cut an infinitely large pancake into as many pieces as possible, in a new take on an old puzzle.
item.dc:creator: Siobhan Roberts

item.title: A Bite-Size Column About Delight and Wonder in Science
item.description: In Trilobites, reporters aim to share new findings in the science world, be it interspecies friendships or discoveries of ancient fossils.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Ewing

item.title: Cows Use Tools, Too, New Study Finds
item.description: A pet cow named Veronika can scratch her own back with a broom — the first scientifically documented case of tool use in cows, researchers say.
item.dc:creator: Emily Anthes

item.title: Artemis II Moon Mission: NASA Completes Giant Rocket’s Slow Ride to Launchpad
item.description: The Space Launch System and Orion capsule were transported to the launchpad before an astronaut mission that could launch as soon as Feb. 6.
item.dc:creator: Kenneth Chang

item.title: If the Volcanic Eruption Doesn’t Scare You, the Mudflow Should
item.description: Studying tree rings helped scientists pinpoint when Mount Rainier last sent a lahar down its steep slopes, which could help planners anticipate future mudflows.
item.dc:creator: Katherine Kornei
item.media:credit: Max Whittaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: Knowing the year that the largest mudflow occurred could make it possible to better predict future muddy outbursts.

item.title: Joel Primack, Physicist Who Helped Explain the Cosmos, Dies at 80
item.description: A professor at the University of California, Santa Cruz, he was a key contributor to a landmark paper that laid out how the universe came to look like it does today.
item.dc:creator: Kenneth Chang

item.title: For the World’s Food Supply, Federal Funding Cuts Have Long-Term Impacts
item.description: The U.S. Agency for International Development has been a major supporter of global agriculture research. Now many studies are being scuttled or scaled back.
item.dc:creator: Ted Alcorn
item.category: United States Agency for International Development
item.media:credit: Taylor Glascock for The New York Times
item.media:description: Brian Diers was employed by the University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign soybean “innovation lab” before it was shuttered. Now he works with soybean plants on a volunteer basis.

item.title: Scientists Set Up Camp on Thwaites Glacier in Antarctica
item.description: Low clouds have lifted long enough for helicopters to ferry scientists and their gear to a fast-melting glacier on the edge of Antarctica.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times

item.title: Democrats Seek Investigation of $3.5 Million Deal by Interior Official’s Husband
item.description: Records show that Karen Budd-Falen, a top Interior Department official, didn’t disclose a contract between her husband and the developers of a mine approved by the agency.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.media:description: Karen Budd-Falen in 2017. Ms. Budd-Falen, currently the third-ranking official at the Interior Department, also worked at the agency during the first Trump administration.

item.title: Will ‘Psychiatry’s Bible’ Add a Postpartum Psychosis Diagnosis?
item.description: Leaders of the D.S.M., the world’s most influential psychiatric manual, have been split for more than five years over whether to recognize postpartum psychosis as a distinct disorder.
item.dc:creator: Ellen Barry and Pam Belluck
item.category: Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (Book)
item.media:credit: Alycee Byrd for The New York Times
item.media:description: Emily Swilinski of Greensboro, N.C., did not have a history of mental health issues when, after giving birth to her first child, she suddenly had racing thoughts, trouble sleeping, and began hallucinating that her dog was speaking to her.

item.title: A Look Through a Century of Times Reporting From Antarctica
item.description: Generations of Times journalists have journeyed there with scientists. Their coverage traces humankind’s changing relationship with the most mysterious continent.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong
item.media:credit: The New York Times, St. Louis Post-Dispatch
item.media:description: One of the dog teams of the Byrd Expedition resting in the foothills near the Axel Heiberg Glacier on the Ross Ice Shelf in Antarctica in 1930.

item.title: 3 Policy Moves Likely to Change Health Care for Older People
item.description: Two regulatory rollbacks, along with a new A.I. experiment in Medicare, raise some worrisome questions.
item.dc:creator: Paula Span
item.category: Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services

item.title: World’s First Treaty to Protect the High Seas Becomes Law
item.description: Over two decades after negotiations began, the High Seas Treaty is designed to protect biodiversity in international waters by enabling conservation zones.
item.dc:creator: Sachi Kitajima Mulkey
item.category: United Nations Convention on Biological Diversity
item.media:description: The High Seas Treaty represents the first time that the vast majority of international waters, which lie outside of any country’s jurisdiction and cover nearly half the globe, can be protected.

item.title: No Link Between Acetaminophen in Pregnancy and Autism, a Study Finds
item.description: The review looked at more than three dozen studies and found no evidence that acetaminophen increased the risk of neurodevelopmental disorders in children.
item.dc:creator: Azeen Ghorayshi

item.title: Supreme Court to Decide if the Pesticide Roundup Is Shielded From Lawsuits
item.description: The case could affect thousands of claims that the widely used weedkiller causes cancer.
item.dc:creator: Karen Zraick and Hiroko Tabuchi
item.media:description: Roundup, used widely on cropland, has faced controversy over its effects on human health.

item.title: Virginia Coastal Offshore Wind Project Can Continue, Judge Rules
item.description: Construction can continue on an $11.2 billion project off the coast of Virginia, said to be 70 percent complete.
item.dc:creator: Brad Plumer
item.media:description: Wind turbine components at a staging area for the Coastal Virginia Offshore Wind project in Portsmouth, Va., last month.

item.title: For Men, How Much Alcohol Is Too Much?
item.description: Federal officials working on the new dietary guidelines had considered limiting men to one drink daily. The final advice was only that everyone should drink less.
item.dc:creator: Roni Caryn Rabin
item.media:credit: Robert Wright for The New York Times
item.media:description: “There are a lot of reasons people drink alcohol,” said one epidemiologist who led an advisory panel on alcohol. “What we’re saying is health shouldn’t be one of them.”

item.title: Empire Wind Project Can Resume Construction, Judge Rules
item.description: A federal judge said the Empire Wind project off Long Island would suffer “irreparable harm” if the Trump administration continued to hold up work.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.category: Bureau of Ocean Energy Management, Regulation and Enforcement
item.media:description: The South Brooklyn Marine Terminal, the staging site for the Empire Wind offshore wind project.

item.title: U.S. Cuts Health Aid and Ties It to Funding Pledges by African Governments
item.description: The Trump administration has signed $11 billion in agreements with African nations, in deals tied to foreign policy goals.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Nolen
item.category: United States Agency for International Development
item.media:credit: Gulshan Khan for The New York Times
item.media:description: A health clinic in Mhlosheni, Eswatini, in May. Health funding from the U.S. to Eswatini — where a quarter of adults live with H.I.V. — would drop by 34 percent under the new agreement between the two countries.

item.title: Who is left on the International Space Station?
item.dc:creator: Kenneth Chang
item.media:credit: NASA, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The International Space Station, seen from the Crew Dragon Endeavour in 2021.

item.title: How NASA deals with astronauts’ medical needs on the I.S.S.
item.dc:creator: Kenneth Chang
item.media:description: Jeanette Epps practicing C.P.R. on her fellow NASA astronaut Mike Barratt on the International Space Station in 2024.

item.title: What happens during the astronauts’ return to Earth?
item.dc:creator: Kenneth Chang
item.media:description: A Crew Dragon capsule undocking from the space station last March.

item.title: Is it risky to fly a sick astronaut home to Earth?
item.dc:creator: Kenneth Chang
item.media:description: A SpaceX capsule landing in the Pacific Ocean off the Southern California coast last August.

item.title: NASA Astronauts Return to Earth After Medical Evacuation From International Space Station
item.description: The members of Crew-11 — two American, one Russian and one Japanese — splashed down after one became ill, prompting an early return.
item.dc:creator: Kenneth Chang
item.media:description: From left, the astronauts Oleg Platonov of Roscosmos, Michael Fincke and Zena Cardman of NASA and Kimiya Yui of JAXA, the Japanese space agency, inside a Crew Dragon capsule just after splashing down.

item.title: Kaiser Permanente Agrees to Pay $556 Million to Settle Medicare Overbilling Claims
item.description: The Justice Department and whistle-blowers accused the major health insurer of overbilling the government for about $1 billion under the private plans.
item.dc:creator: Reed Abelson and Margot Sanger-Katz
item.media:credit: Rachel Woolf for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dr. James Taylor, a physician and coding expert who worked for Kaiser Permanente, was one of the whistle-blowers who flagged the overbilling. “The cash monster was insatiable,” he said.

item.title: NASA Begins Astronaut Space Station Medical Evacuation: What to Know
item.description: Four astronauts departed from the I.S.S. about a month earlier than scheduled because a crew member, who was not identified, has an undisclosed medical issue.
item.dc:creator: Kenneth Chang
item.media:description: The International Space Station crew members in their Crew Dragon pressure suits on Jan. 9. Clockwise from bottom left: NASA astronaut Mike Fincke, Roscosmos cosmonaut Oleg Platonov, NASA astronaut Zena Cardman and JAXA astronaut Kimiya Yui.

item.title: Weather Detours a Scientific Expedition to Antarctica’s Thwaites Glacier
item.description: Bad weather has postponed attempts to set up camp on the Thwaites Glacier. So researchers got onto the sea ice and met a local.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times

item.title: What a Wolf Pup’s Stomach Revealed About the Woolly Rhino’s Extinction
item.description: Scientists prepared a high-quality sequence of the giant mammal’s genome based on a specimen preserved in Siberian permafrost.
item.dc:creator: Ari Daniel

item.title: Toby Kiers, World Champion of Mycorrhizal Fungus
item.description: This year’s recipient of the Tyler Prize for Environmental Achievement talks about “punk science,” microbial economics and thinking like a mycorrhizal fungus.
item.dc:creator: Alan Burdick
item.media:credit: Tomas Munita for The New York Times
